title: Paul's Charge to Timothy
shortSummary: In 1 Timothy chapter 1, the Apostle Paul instructs Timothy to guard sound doctrine and warns against false teachings that lead believers astray. Paul emphasizes the purpose of the law, recounts his own transformation by Christ's mercy, and charges Timothy to fight the good fight of faith with a clear conscience.
timeline: c. AD 63-65 - Paul's First Imprisonment, during which he writes to Timothy

keyCharacters.name: Paul
keyCharacters.description: The apostle and author of the letter, who instructs Timothy and reflects on his own past and ministry.

keyCharacters.name: Timothy
keyCharacters.description: Paul’s spiritual son and young pastor in Ephesus, entrusted with preserving sound doctrine and leading the church.

keyCharacters.name: Hymenaeus
keyCharacters.description: A false teacher mentioned as an example of one who has shipwrecked his faith and was delivered to Satan.

keyCharacters.name: Alexander
keyCharacters.description: Another false teacher like Hymenaeus, disciplined for blasphemy and error.

definitions.definition: In the KJV, 'charity' refers to love, specifically the selfless, sacrificial love that is the fulfillment of the law.
The Mosaic Law given to Israel, which Paul explains is good when used properly but is designed to expose sin, not to justify the righteous.
One who speaks irreverently or disrespectfully about God or sacred things.
A metaphor describing those who have abandoned or destroyed their faith through false teaching or disobedience.

outline.heading: Paul’s Greeting and Charge to Timothy
outline.description: Paul opens with a personal greeting to Timothy and instructs him to remain in Ephesus to oppose false teachers promoting myths and genealogies, emphasizing that the goal of the commandment is love from a pure heart and sincere faith.

outline.heading: Warning Against False Teachers and Misuse of the Law
outline.description: Paul describes those who have deviated into meaningless arguments and desire to be teachers without understanding, clarifying that the law is meant for the unrighteous, listing sins that contradict sound doctrine.

outline.heading: Paul’s Testimony of Mercy and Grace
outline.description: Paul thanks Christ for enabling him and recounts his former life as a blasphemer and persecutor, highlighting the abundant grace and mercy he received as an example of Christ’s patience toward sinners.

outline.heading: Final Charge and Warning to Timothy
outline.description: Paul charges Timothy to fight the good fight of faith with a good conscience, warning about those who have shipwrecked their faith, specifically naming Hymenaeus and Alexander as examples.

application: Guard sound doctrine carefully and avoid distractions from false teachings that do not build up faith.
Recognize the purpose of God’s law as revealing sin and leading us to Christ, not as a means of self-justification.
Embrace God’s mercy and grace, remembering that even the worst sinner can be transformed by Christ.
Maintain a good conscience through faith and obedience to God’s Word to endure spiritual warfare.

keyVerses.text: Now the end of the commandment is charity out of a pure heart, and of a good conscience, and of faith unfeigned:
keyVerses.significance: This verse summarizes the ultimate purpose of God's commandments: genuine love motivated by sincere faith and a clear conscience.

keyVerses.text: This is a faithful saying, and worthy of all acceptation, that Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners; of whom I am chief.
keyVerses.significance: Paul’s humble confession highlights the core gospel truth that Christ’s mission is to save sinners, offering hope to all.

keyVerses.text: This charge I commit unto thee, son Timothy, according to the prophecies which went before on thee, that thou by them mightest war a good warfare;
keyVerses.significance: Paul entrusts Timothy with the responsibility to fight the spiritual battle faithfully, encouraging perseverance in ministry.

keyVerses.text: Holding faith, and a good conscience; which some having put away concerning faith have made shipwreck:
keyVerses.significance: Faith combined with a good conscience is essential for spiritual stability, warning against the dangers of abandoning these.
